subject: Re: Parameterized test with default value
msgSnippet: ... What Parameterized runner does it takes a Collection that returns by @Parameterized method run over it, for each Object[] calls constructor of your class
messageBody:
--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "kelvsyc" <kelvsyc@...> wrote:
>
> I've just gotten into parameterized testing and customized JUnit4
> Runners, but I have a few questions:
>
> How do I go about making a parameterized test for which a single
> default parameter value is provided if a list of parameter values is
> not given? (It appears to me that you may need to have a custom
> runner that's similar to Parameterized)
>
> Furthermore, suppose I have a subclass of this test, which defines a
> second parameter, which, unlike the first, is a required parameter
> (ie. I can choose to have my list of parameters as either two values
> or a single, which would assume the usage of a default value). How
> would I go about doing that? (Would I need to use a different runner?)
>
> How would I generalize this to any number of parameters (required and
> optional)?
>

What Parameterized runner does it takes a Collection that returns by
@Parameterized method run over it, for each Object[] calls constructor
of your class with supplied variables (that initialize data-members
that will be used by your test method) and calls test method. The
naive way to handle it is to define couple of constructor that will
call one to another and supplying default values. For each entry in
Collecion appropriate constructor will be called. It is nice, but
unfortunately is not working. It happens that Parameterized runner
enforce you to have only one constructor. Under these circumstances
your question is equivalent how can you supplied default values to the
attribute in the function (constructor in your case). In Java there is
no way to do it (other then overloading). So there is no way out for
now, at least as far as I know.

> Finally, what if I wanted my parameterized tests to be named via some
> naming function (instead of serially numbered like Parameterized)?
>

Parameterized runner is written is such a way that there is no easy to
extend it in order to achieve this. The main obstacle is that you
can't override "new TestClassRunnerForParameters(...)" in private
static runners method, so you actually hast to rewrite this class
completely.
